{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} '''Saul Yaffie''', {{aka}} '''Paul Jeffay''', (1898–1957) was a Scottish Jewish artist.
== Early life == Saul Yaffie was born in Blythswood, [[Glasgow]] on 29 April 1898. His mother was Kate Yaffie (née Karkinofski), and his father, Bernard Yaffie, was a master tailor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Like many Russian Jews, Kate and Bernard Yaffie fled persecution in Russia during a wave of anti-Jewish pogroms triggered by the assassination of [[Tsar Alexander II]] in 1881.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Jewish community in Scotland|url=http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/higherscottishhistory/migrationandempire/experienceofimmigrants/jewish.asp|website=Education Scotland|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Saul's father was naturalised as a British citizen by the time that Saul himself was three; a Bernard Yaffie is recorded as living at Abbortsford Place in the old [[Gorbals]], where the young Saul spent the early years of his childhood.<ref>{{cite web|title=Census|url=http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/|website=Scotland's People|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> The Yaffies were not unique in their situation: the Gorbals was the centre of Scotland's Jewish community and home to a large proportion of Glasgow's immigrants throughout the early 20th century.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Jewish community in Scotland|url=http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/higherscottishhistory/migrationandempire/experienceofimmigrants/jewish.asp|website=Education Scotland|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Over time, there was a movement to some of the more affluent communities in Glasgow, such as [[Pollokshields]] and [[Garnethill]], as many Jewish families gradually improved their social and economic situation.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Jewish community in Scotland|url=http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/higherscottishhistory/migrationandempire/experienceofimmigrants/jewish.asp|website=Education Scotland|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Like these, the Yaffies also experienced a time of good fortune, moving to a more agreeable address on Sinclair Drive, [[Cathcart]] as Bernard's tailoring business prospered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Census|url=http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/|website=Scotland's People|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref>
== Education and military service == Saul attended day classes in drawing and painting, modelling, and life drawing at [[Glasgow School of Art|The Glasgow School of Art]] from 1912 to 1919.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> During the [[World War I|First World War]], he was required to interrupt his studies to serve in the King's Own Scottish Borderers in 1916/17. Although subject to military conscription, Yaffie reached the rank of corporal during his service.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Prior to his conscription Yaffie engaged in munitions work, something that was recorded in the GSA's student registers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref>
== Later life == The post-war economic depression that affected the country during the 1920s, also affected the Yaffie family directly: Bernard Yaffie's business suffered greatly, and the family eventually emigrated to Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Saul did not emigrate with his family, choosing instead to stay in Europe, and relocate to [[Paris]] where he continued his artistic practice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Now married, Saul sought to escape persecution in Europe by returning to the UK before the [[World War II|Second World War]] with his wife, Estusia. The two settled in Manchester, but returned to France after the war.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yaffie, Saul|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=core/search&subjectid=677|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref>
== Death and legacy == Saul Yaffie is listed in the Glasgow School of Art's World War One Roll of Honour.<ref>{{cite web|title=Roll of Honour|url=http://www.gsaarchives.net/archon/index.php?p=collections/findingaid&id=462&rootcontentid=16306&q=roll+of+honour#id16306|website=Archives and Collections: Glasgow School of Art|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> He later went by the name Paul Jeffay, and much of his work is signed under this name.<ref>{{cite web|title=Family History|url=http://www.sjac.org.uk/collections/family-history-genealogy/|website=Scottish Jewish Archives Centre|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> Saul Yaffie/Paul Jeffay died in Paris in 1957; his work is included the [[Ben Uri Gallery]]'s Collection of Jewish émigré artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Collection: Paul Jeffay|url=http://www.benuri.org.uk/public/?collection-details=1399|website=Ben Uri|publisher=Ben Uri Galleri|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref>

'''Social Betterment Properties International''' (SBPI) is a California-based entity associated with the [[Church of Scientology]], for which it operates as a real estate arm. The organisation states that its purpose is to "develop and maintain buildings and other real estate utilized by social betterment organizations carrying out programs that utilize technology and methods developed by [[L. Ron Hubbard]] and that are associated with and supported by the [[Scientology religion|Scientology]]".<ref name="VCStar-5-Apr-2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.vcstar.com/business/scientology-linked-nonprofit-buys-larry-hagmans|title=Scientology-linked nonprofit buys Larry Hagman's Ojai estate|last=Hoops|first=Stephanie|work=Ventura County Star|date=April 5, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> It has been involved in the purchase of a number of properties in the United States and Canada in order to advance Scientology's "social betterment" programs, notably the controversial [[Narconon]] drug rehabilitation program.
==Status==
SBPI states in its articles of incorporation that it is "an integrated auxiliary of the [[Church of Scientology International]]", organised "to support Church of Scientology International by owning and managing real property used in Church of Scientology International's charitable public benefit program."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xenu-directory.net/documents/corporate/sbpi-incorporation.pdf|title=SBPI Articles of Incorporation|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> Established in 2003, it is registered as a [[501(c) organization]] (i.e. a [[tax-exempt]] [[nonprofit organization]]) and is not required to file an annual return with the [[IRS]] as it is designated as a religious organization. SBPI is co-located with the Church of Scientology International at 6331 Hollywood Boulevard, Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Betterment Properties International|url=http://www.guidestar.org/organizations/86-1067526/social-betterment-properties-international.aspx|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> In 2008, an IRS Form 990 filed by SBPI stated that it had $39,647,311 of assets.<ref name="990-2008">{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/224963946/Church-of-Scientology-Social-Betterment-Properties-International-990-2008-Net-assets-39-573-456|title=Social Betterment Properties International - Form 900|date=2008|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref>
==Activities==
According to SPBI's IRS Form 990, it owed three properties as of 2008:
* Headquarters of [[Applied Scholastics|Applied Scholastics International]] at [[Spanish Lake, Missouri]]; * Narconon Arrowhead property at [[Canadian, Oklahoma]]; * Headquarters of [[Citizens Commission on Human Rights|Citizens Commission on Human Rights International]] in Los Angeles, California.<ref name="990-2008" />
The organisation's property portfolio has expanded since then. In April 2013, it was disclosed that SBPI had paid $5 million to purchase the estate of the late actor [[Larry Hagman]] at [[Ojai, California]].<ref name="VCStar-5-Apr-2015" /> The purpose of this purchase was not disclosed but [[Mike Rinder]], the former head of the church's [[Office of Special Affairs]], has suggested that it may be intended for use as a "celebrity Narconon".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tony-ortega/scientology-pays-5-millio_b_3028043.html|title=Scientology Pays $5 Million for Larry Hagman's Ojai Estate: And Here's Why|last=Ortega|first=Tony|work=The Huffington Post|date=April 8, 2013|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref>
Also in 2013, SBPI purchased the former [[Trout Run (retreat)|Trout Run]] retreat near [[Thurmont, Maryland]] with the intention of converting it into a Narconon facility. The property was purchased for $4.85 million by a [[Delaware]] corporation, West Coast Property Investments Inc., which then turned Trout Run over to SBPI.<ref name="Carignan">{{cite news|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/news/environment/natural_resource/myths-obscure-trout-run-s-past/article_4fad9e69-6a00-5a69-82c1-87989f47aa52.html|title=Myths obscure Trout Run's past|work=The Frederick News-Post|last=Carignan|first=Sylvia|date=May 30, 2015|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> Although zoning restrictions meant that establishing such a facility at Trout Run would ordinarily be impossible, using it as a group home would be permitted under local ordinances if the property was listed on the county's historic register.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/news/politics_and_government/governmental_and_political_topics/health_and_welfare/scientology-affiliates-plan-recovery-center-at-historic-retreat/article_0fb90e47-9dde-57a6-9368-df64a7dca59c.html|title=Scientology affiliates plan recovery center at historic retreat|author1=Bethany Rodgers|author2=Sylvia Carignan|work=The Frederick News-Post|date=April 4, 2015|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref> Narconon sought to obtain such a designation but was rejected by the local county council.<ref name="WaPo2-6-2015">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/frederick-council-rejects-historic-designation-for-trout-run-a-blow-for-a-scientology-backed-drug-rehab/2015/06/02/e3f12b74-0931-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|title=Frederick Council rejects historic designation for Trout Run, a blow for a Scientology-backed drug rehab|last1=Rosenwald|first1=Michael S.|last2=Bogage|first2=Jacob|work=The Washington Post|date=June 2, 2015|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> As of August 1, 2015, the decision is currently being appealed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/news/politics_and_government/frederick-county-council-s-decision-on-trout-run-questioned-in/article_3674d3e2-992a-533a-861f-74600cb64b93.html|title=Frederick County Council's decision on Trout Run questioned in court|last=Fifield|first=Jen|work=The Frederick News-Post|date=July 6, 2015|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, SBPI acquired a parcel of land in an isolated part of the Canadian town [[Milton, Ontario]] and applied for permission to establish a Narconon center there. It was turned down in October 2014 by a local municipal committee,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2015/02/09/narconon-strikes-out-in-second-ontario-town.html|title=Narconon rehab strikes out in second Ontario town|last=Gallant|first=Jacques|work=Toronto Star|date=February 9, 2015|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> a decision that was upheld on appeal in June 2015 by the [[Ontario Municipal Board]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ici.radio-canada.ca/regions/ontario/2015/06/09/006-eglise-scientologie-centre-desintoxication-milton-deboutee.shtml|title=Centre de désintoxication: l'Église de scientologie déboutée|publisher=Radio Canada|date=June 9, 2015|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref>

{{Other uses|Over-soul (disambiguation)}} "'''The Over-Soul'''" is an essay by [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]], first published in 1841. With the human [[soul]] as its overriding subject, several general themes are treated: (1) the existence and nature of the human soul; (2) the relationship between the soul and the personal ego; (3) the relationship of one human soul to another; and (4) the relationship of the human soul to God. Influence of Eastern religions, including [[Vedanta|Vedantism]], is plainly evident, but the essay also develops ideas long present in the Western tradition, e.g., in the works of [[Plato]], [[Plutarch]], and [[Neoplatonism|Neoplatonists]] like [[Plotinus]] and [[Proclus]] – all of whose writings Emerson read extensively throughout his career<ref>''The Teachers of Emerson'', John S. Harrison, New York: Sturgis & Walton, 1910.</ref><ref>''Emerson: The Mind on Fire'', Robert D. Richardson Jr, Berkeley: University of California Press, 1995 pp. 65-66.</ref> – and [[Emanuel Swedenborg]].
The essay attempts no systematic doctrine, but rather serves as a work of art, something like poetry. Its virtue is in personal insights of the author and the lofty manner of their presentation. Emerson wishes to exhort and direct the reader to an awakening of similar thoughts or sentiments.
With respect to the four themes listed above, the essay presents the following views: (1) the human soul is immortal, and immensely vast and beautiful; (2) our conscious ego is slight and limited in comparison to the soul, despite the fact that we habitually mistake our ego for our true self; (3) at some level, the souls of all people are connected, though the precise manner and degree of this connection is not spelled out; and (4) the essay does not seem to explicitly contradict the traditional Western idea that the soul is created by and has an existence (?) that is similar to God, or rather God exists within us.
''The Over-Soul'' is now considered one of Emerson's greatest writings.
==History== The essay includes the following passage:
{{quote|The Supreme Critic on the errors of the past and the present, and the only prophet of that which must be, is that great nature in which we rest, as the earth lies in the soft arms of the atmosphere; that Unity, that '''Over-soul''', within which every man's particular being is contained and made one with all other; that common heart.<ref name="ReferenceA">Over-soul, from ''Essays: First Series,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson, 1841</ref>}}
For Emerson the term denotes a supreme underlying unity which transcends duality or plurality, much in keeping with the philosophy of [[Advaita Vedanta]]. This non-Abrahamic interpretation of Emerson's use of the term is further supported by the fact that Emerson's Journal records in 1845 suggest that he was reading the [[Bhagavad Gita]] and [[Henry Thomas Colebrooke]]'s essays on the [[Vedas]].<ref>''India in the United States: Contribution of India and Indians in the United States of America'', Sachin N. Pradhan, SP Press International, Inc., 1996, p 12.</ref> Emerson goes on in the same essay to further articulate his view of this dichotomy between phenomenal plurality and transcendental unity:
{{quote|We live in succession, in division, in parts, in particles. Meantime within man is the soul of the whole; the wise silence; the universal beauty, to which every part and particle is equally related, the eternal ONE. And this deep power in which we exist and whose beatitude is all accessible to us, is not only self-sufficing and perfect in every hour, but the act of seeing and the thing seen, the seer and the spectacle, the subject and the object, are one. We see the world piece by piece, as the sun, the moon, the animal, the tree; but the whole, of which these are shining parts, is the soul.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>}}
"Over-soul" has more recently come to be used by Eastern philosophers such as [[Meher Baba]] and others as the closest English language equivalent of the Vedic concept of ''[[Paramatman]]''.<ref>''God Speaks, The Theme of Creation and Its Purpose'', Meher Baba, Dodd Meade. 1955. Sec. Ed. pp. 1 ff., 156, 172</ref> (In [[Sanskrit]] the word ''param'' means "supreme" and ''atman'' means "soul"; thus ''Paramatman'' literally means "Supreme-Soul".<ref>http://www.vedabase.net/p/param</ref>) The term is used frequently in discussion of Eastern metaphysics and has also entered western vernacular. In this context, the term "Over-soul" is understood as the collective indivisible Soul, of which all individual souls or identities are included. The experience of this underlying reality of the indivisible "I am" state of the Over-soul is said to be veiled from the human mind by [[sanskara (philosophy)|sanskara]]s, or impressions, acquired over the course of evolution and reincarnation. Such past impressions form a kind of sheath between the Over-soul and its true identity, as they give rise to the tendency of identification with the gross differentiated body. Thus the world, as [[apperception|apperceived]] through the impressions of the past appears plural, while reality experienced in the present, unencumbered by past impressions (the unconditioned or liberated mind), perceives itself as the One indivisible totality, i.e. the Over-soul.

[[File:British Museum Asia 45 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Gilded bronze [[Statue of Tara]], Sri Lanka, 8th century CE. With her right hand, the bodhisattva makes varadamudra, the gesture of charity or gift-giving, while her left hand may originally have held a lotus.]] '''Varadamudra''' is a [[mudra]], and it indicates a gesture by the hand and symbolizes dispensing of [[:wikt:boon|boons]]. For varadamudra, right hand is used. It is held out, with palm uppermost and the fingers pointing downwards. Varadamudra and [[abhayamudra]] are the most common of several other mudras seen on images and [[Iconography|icons]] relating to [[Indian religions]].

'''Women in [[Shinto]]''' occupy a unique role in the indigenous Japanese traditions of Shinto, including a unique form of participation as temple stewards and shamans, or ''miko''. Though a ban on Shinto priestesses was lifted after 1945, the number of women priests in Shinto is a small fraction of contemporary clergy.
==History of women in Shinto== Women in Shinto have long been described as miko, or "Children of God." They are consistently seen as conduits between spirits and men, though men are then seen as the actors who implement the will of the spirit.<ref name="Okano-Earhart">{{cite book|last1=Okano|first1=Haruko|authorlink1=Summary: Woman and the Shinto Religion|editor1-last=Earhart|editor1-first=H.Byron|title=Religion in the Japanese experience : sources and interpretations|date=1997|publisher=Wadsworth Pub. Co.|location=Belmont, CA|isbn=0534524613|pages=35–38|edition=2nd}}</ref>
===Mythological beginnings=== The diverse roles of women in Shinto myths make it difficult for scholars to generalize about women's roles at Shinto's origin.<ref name=Ambros /> [[Amateratsu]], the sun goddess, and [[Himiko]], an early shaman queen of Japan, are central figures in the faith. Other goddesses include [[Benten]], a dragon-woman of good luck, and [[Inari Ōkami|Inari]], a rice goddess who takes the form of [[kitsune]], a [[vixen]] (female fox) at many Shinto shrines.<ref name=Monaghan /> The [[Kojiki]], a collection of stories which form Shinto practices, purport to be collected from a courtesan, [[Hieda no Are]], and written down at the request of an Empress, [[Empress Gemmei of Japan|Gemmei]].<ref name=Monaghan>{{cite book|last1=Monaghan|first1=Patricia|title=Encyclopedia of Goddesses and Heroines|date=2014|publisher=New World Library|page=140}}</ref>
In the earliest records of Shinto, from the 2nd to 7th centuries, women were valued as representatives, and carriers, of fertility. There is debate among scholars as to the extent of which this translated into political power within society or within Shinto practice, with some evidence suggesting a deferential tendency to women from male counterparts.<ref name="Okano" /> Some scholars suggest that priesthood at this time was seen as a dual role shared by men and women, operating together, often as brother and sister.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" />
===Royal High Priestesses at Ise shrine=== According to the mythology of Japan described in the ''[[Nihon Shoki]],'' nieces or daughters of the Emperor or Empress served as intermediaries at one of Shinto's holiest sites, the [[Ise Grand Shrine|Ise shrine]], beginning in the 7th century.<ref name=Bock>{{cite book|last1=Bock|first1=Felicia|title=Engishiki: Procedures of the Engi era|date=1970|publisher=Sophia University|location=Tokyo|pages=51–52}}</ref> These priestesses served to connect the reigning Emperor to the purported divine origin of that Emperor's power, and remained an official position until the 14th century.<ref name="Yusa 1993">{{cite book|last1 = Michigo|first1 = Yusa|authorlink1 = |editor1-last = |editor1-first = |editor1-link = |title = Women in Shinto: Images Remembered|date = 1993|publisher = State University of New York Press|location = Albany|isbn = 978-0791416891|pages = }}</ref> These priestesses retreated to the Royal Palace for a year after being chosen, followed by another year in seclusion, before moving to the Shrine at Ise, where they participated in, and watched over, purification rituals for about 11 years.<ref name=Bock /> Once retired, the priestess could marry.<ref name="Ambros">{{cite book|last1 = Ambros|first1 = Barbara|title = Women in Japanese Religions|date = 2015|publisher = New York University Press|location = New York}}</ref>
===The Heian era=== [[File:Kamigamo-Jinjya National Treasure World heritage Kyoto 国宝・世界遺産 上賀茂神社 京都11.JPG|thumb|Kamo shrine, Kyoto]] The Heian era saw an early synthesis of Buddhist and Shinto beliefs in Japan, and the integration of a Confucian legal system from China.<ref name=Ambros /> The introduction of a patriarchal Confucian system, combined with the Buddhist concepts of women as "unclean", resulted in a decline in power for female shaman and shrine priestesses.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" /><ref name=Ambros /> For example, women no longer had any claim to official positions at shrines,<ref name=Ambros /> and [[miko]] were limited to maintenance and upkeep.<ref name=Cornyetz>{{cite book|last1=Cornyetz|first1=Nina|title=Dangerous Women, Deadly Words: Phallic Fantasy and Modernity|date=1999|publisher=Stanford University Press}}</ref>
Some scholars suggest that, while spiritual power was considered equal among male and female priests in this time period, male priests nonetheless wielded larger influence and political power.<ref name="Yanagita 1">{{cite book|last1=Yanagita|first1=Kunio|title=Works of Yanagita Kunio|date=1962|publisher=Chikuma Shohu|location=Tokyo|pages=7–22}}</ref> Others suggest that the role of women in Shinto is a contemporary myth without connection to ancient Shinto practice.<ref name="Cornyetz"/>
Ise shrine priestess maintained their role during this period, and were complemented by a similar position at the [[Kamo Shrine|Kamo shrine]] in Kyoto.<ref name=Ambros /> Like Ise priestesses, those at Kamo served one year at the Imperial Palace before overseeing the shrines activities. These priestesses would also perform rituals and purifications, including fasting and overseeing ceremonies.<ref name=Bock />
===Tokugawa and Meiji era=== During the [[Tokugawa shogunate]], all Shinto priests were consolidated under the control of the [[Yoshida Shintō|Yoshida]] family, which limited the power of female priests.<ref name=Routledge>{{cite book|last1=Kramarae|first1=Cheris|last2=Spender|first2=Dale|title=Routledge International Encyclopedia of Women: Global Women's Issues and Knowledge|date=2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135963156|page=1847}}</ref> This prohibition was carried through into the [[Meiji period|Meiji era]], which sought to regulate Shinto practices. Here, a nationalist movement toward modernization called for the elimination of magical elements that had come to be most closely associated with women.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" /> This trend continued until the defeat of [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japan]].<ref name="Routledge"/> After the defeat of Imperial Japan, Shinto and the state were rendered legally distinct, with prohibitions on state involvement, and later, women were again permitted to become priests.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" />
==Shinto taboos applicable to women==
===Exclusion from sacred sites=== [[File:Omine 2.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Sign announcing the prohibition of women climbers]]
Women were excluded from many Shinto shrines and sacred mountains up to about 1872, a practice known as {{Nihongo||女人結界|nyonin kekkai}}.<ref name=Fumiko /> This practice was abolished under the Meiji constitution.<ref name=Fumiko>{{cite journal|last1=Fumiko|first1=Miyazaki|title=Female Pilgrims and Mt. Fuji: Changing Perspectives on the Exclusion of Women|journal=Monumenta Nipponica|date=1 January 2005|volume=60|issue=3|pages=339–391|doi=10.1353/mni.2005.0034|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/monumenta_nipponica/summary/v060/60.3fumiko.html|issn=1880-1390|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://muse.jhu.edu/ Project MUSE]}}}}</ref>
Some historians suggest that the practice may have originated from folk tales about women who were turned to stone or brought on natural disasters as they approached sacred sites on mountains,<ref name=Fumiko /><ref name=Yanagita>{{cite book|last1=Yanagita|first1=Kunio|title=Teihon: Yanagita Kunio zenshû (volume 9)|date=1962|publisher=Chikuma Shobo|location=Tokyo|pages=123–146|language=Japanese}}</ref> or owing to the choice of religious ascetics that rejected interactions with women, and commonly lived high in the mountains.<ref name=Fumiko /><ref name=Suzuki-2002>{{cite book|last1=Masataka|first1=Suzuki|title=Nyonin kinsei|date=2002|publisher=Yoshikawa Kōbunkan|location=Tōkyō|isbn=464205538X|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/nyonin-kinsei/oclc/49728832|language=Japanese}}</ref> Others suggest the prohibition is influenced by Buddhist doctrine against sexual relationships between monks and nuns.<ref name=Fumiko /><ref name=Ushiyama>{{cite journal|last1=Ushiyama|first1=Yoshiyuki|title='Nyonin kinsei' sairon ("he System of Exclusion of Women" Reconsidered")|journal=Sangaku shugen|date=1996|volume=17|pages=1–11|language=Japanese}}</ref>
Some examples of the practice remain in contemporary Japan. A sign at a World Heritage site, [[Mount Ōmine|Mt. Omine]] in [[Nara, Nara|Nara]], forbids women from climbing to the top, which has triggered a number of controversial protests.<ref name=Takemaru>{{cite book|last1=Takemaru|first1=Naoko|title=Women in the Language and Society of Japan|date=2010|publisher=McFarland}}</ref> Some shrines also ask recent mothers not to pass through torii gates to enter shrines for 72 days after childbirth.<ref name=Takemaru />
Women had been forbidden from participation in Yamakasa, parades in which Shinto shrines are carried through a town, until 2001.<ref name=Takemaru />
===Blood pollution=== Women's menstrual blood is a taboo in Shinto, thought to be influenced by the popularity of the Buddhist {{Nihongo|Blood Pond Sutra|血盆経|Ketsubonkyô}}. This doctrine preached that women were condemned to a blood pond hell for the sin of pollution through menstrual blood; only the prayer could spare them.<ref name=Fumiko /><ref name="Matsuoka 1988">{{cite book|last1=Matsuoka|first1=Hideaki|editor1-last=Kenkyûkai|editor1-first=Sôgô Joseishi|title=Nihon joseishi ronshû: Shûkyô to josei (5)|date=1988|publisher=Yoshikawa Kôbunkan|location=Tokyo|language=Japanese|chapter=Wagakuni ni okeru Ketsubonkyô shinkô ni tsuite no ichikôsatsu}}</ref> Though Buddhist in origin, Shinto facilities emulated this practice in their teaching, encourage women, and men who had contact with menstrual women, to avoid shrines.<ref name=Fumiko /><ref name=Ushiyama />
==Women Shinto priests== In Shinto, female priests are allowed, but remain rare, and take on the male role of priests from recent history, more so than the traditional Shamanistic role of women in early Shinto.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" /> More common roles for women in the clergy are ''[[miko]]'', shrine stewards who assist the chief priest. Outside of organized Shinto, however, an increasing number of women are taking the title "miko" and tying it to original Shinto practices such as fortune-telling and healing arts.<ref name="Okano-Earhart" />
Though 20 women per year graduate from [[Kokugakuin University]] with credentials for priesthood, less than two per year become clergy.<ref name=Karan>{{cite book|last1=Karan|first1=Pradyumna|title=Japan in the 21st Century: Environment, Economy, and Society|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|pages=72}}</ref> In 2001, the [[Association of Shinto Shrines]] estimated that there were fewer than 25 women priests in Tokyo.<ref name=Karan />
A ban on female priests was lifted during World War Two, reflecting smaller family sizes and a shrinking interest in religion within Japan,<ref name="Karan"/> as well as a labor shortage after the war.<ref name="Kobayashi">{{cite journal|last1 = Kobayashi|first1 = Akiko|title = Priestesses of Shinto Religion.|journal = Bangalore: Journal of Dharma|date = 2000|pages = 81–98}}</ref> Most of the first women priests were the wives or daughters of priests who went to war. These women were typically preferred over new priests, because they were well versed in their husband’s duties, and already integrated into the community.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nelson|first1=John K.|title=A Year in the Life of a Shinto Shrine|date=1996|publisher=University of Washington Press|page=124}}</ref>
===Special considerations for women priests=== Some Shinto priestesses assert that Shinto is no different from other religions in its treatment of women. Akiko Kobayashi, then a priestess for more than 20 years, has stated that there is "no opposition" from either male priests or those who attend shrines led by women priests.<ref name="Kobayashi"/>
[[Menstruation]] poses a unique challenge to women priests in Shinto, which considers menstrual blood a defilement of sacred spaces.<ref name="Namihara">{{cite journal|last1 = Namihara|first1 = Emiko|title = Pollution on the Folk Belief System.|journal = Current Anthropology|date = 1987|volume = 28|issue = 4|page = |pages = S65–S74 | doi = 10.1086/203590}}</ref> This "red uncleanness" (''aka fujo'', in Japanese) was invoked as a traditional restriction on women’s participation in sacred space from 1872 to just before World War Two.<ref name="Miyazaki">{{cite journal|last1 = Miyazaki|first1 = Fumiko|title = Female Pilgrims and Mt. Fuji: Changing Perspectives on the Exclusion of Women.|journal = Monumenta Nipponica|date = 2005|volume = 60|issue = 3|page = 340|pages = }}</ref> At that point, the Association of Shinto Shrines lifted the ban on women priests and encouraged Shinto shrines to reject the association of "''aka fujo''."<ref name="Smyers">{{cite journal|last1 = Smyers|first1 = Karen A.|title = Women and Shinto: The Relation Between Purity and Pollution.|journal = Japanese Religions.|date = 1983|volume = 12|issue = 4|page = |pages = 7–19}}</ref>
In the modern era, menstrual periods in Shinto priests are controlled through the use of medication.<ref name=Okano>{{cite journal|last1=Okano|first1=Haruko|title=Women and Sexism in Shinto|journal=Japan Christian Review|date=1993|volume=59|page=29|url=https://nirc.nanzan-u.ac.jp/nfile/3517}}</ref><ref name=Fujimura>{{cite book|last1=Fujimura-Fanselow|first1=Kumiko|title=Transforming Japan: How Feminism and Diversity Are Making a Difference|date=2011|publisher=CUNY Press}}</ref>
Some of the most important shrines in National Shinto sects, [[Ise Shrine|Ise]] and [[Atsuta Shrine|Atsuta]], continue to limit the participation of women priests.<ref name="Okano"/> Other obstacles to female priesthood in Shinto include the patronage system, in which an elder priest serves as a mentor for a new priest during religious instruction. This patronage system forbids male priests from instructing women. With a majority of Shinto priests being men, this can pose a challenge for aspiring female priests to find elder mentors.<ref name=Lebra>{{cite book|last1=Lebra|first1=Takie S.|title=Identity, Gender, and Status in Japan: Collected Papers of Takie Lebra|date=2007|publisher=Folkestone|location=Kent, UK|page=186}}</ref>
===Notable women Shinto priests===
Nobuyo Otagaki, a female Shinto priest at Amagasaki Ebisu Shrine, in [[Amagasaki]], [[Hyogo Prefecture]], Japan. Otagaki, the daughter of a Shinto priest, was a graduate of [[Ritsumeikan University]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://profile.ameba.jp/amaebisu/|title = Ameba Profile Page}}</ref> After taking on work as a flight attendant, Otagaki began to study Shinto and became certified into priesthood.<ref name=Nishide /> After moving to New York for two years, she returned to Amagasaki to become a resident priest in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://profile.ameba.jp/amaebisu/|title=神主Nobbyさんのプロフィールページ|website=profile.ameba.jp}}</ref> She took over the Chief Priesthood position from her father in 2012.<ref name=Nishide>{{cite web|last1=Nishide|first1=Takeshi|title=Women’s entry into Shinto priesthood is on the rise|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2014/03/06/lifestyle/womens-entry-into-shinto-priesthood-is-on-the-rise/#.VmI-GdWrTnA|website=Japan Times|publisher=Japan Times|accessdate=5 December 2015}}</ref>
Mihoko Ishii, 58, had been a housewife. She became the priest of Suwa Shrine in Nambu, [[Aomori Prefecture]], after the death of her husband, who had been chief priest.<ref name=Nishide />
==Women in folk Shinto== In popular, localized traditions influenced by, but not officially recognized as,<ref name="Fackler-NYTimes">{{cite web|last1=Fackler|first1=Martin|title=As Japan’s Mediums Die, Ancient Tradition Fades|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/21/world/asia/21japan.html?_r=0|website=New York Times|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=1 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411161542/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/21/world/asia/21japan.html|archivedate=11 April 2015}}</ref> Shinto practice, there is a common figure of [[itako]], or ichiko, or ogamisama: blind mediums. These shaman are always women who enter the calling prior to menstruation. Evidence shows some common aspects of initiation practices for these women among schools in Yamagata, Aomori, and Miyagi prefectures in the 1920s and 1930s. They are trained in various practices, including memorization of Shinto and Buddhist prayers and sutras. Training typically involved cold-water ''mizugori'', or purifying baths, which in its most extreme form can involve complete, sustained drenching by ice-cold water for a period of several days. Once named an itako or ichiko, the woman serves as an intermediary for kami and deceased spirits.<ref name="Blacker">{{cite book|last1=Blacker|first1=Carmen|editor1-last=Earhart|editor1-first=Byron|title=Religion in the Japanese experience : sources and interpretations|date=1997|publisher=Wadsworth Pub. Co.|location=Belmont, CA|isbn=0534524613|pages=130–135|edition=2nd}}</ref>
